economic_context.details: Jean was a cordonnier (shoemaker) who struggled financially. He had spent most of his money during a serious illness 3 years before trial and could not afford to buy leather for his trade - this poverty was cited as reason for devil's seduction. Multiple disputes involved leather exchanges, shoe sales, payment disagreements (gros difference), and attempts to lease rooms or rent houses. Jean also gave 'gresse de cheval' (horse grease) to people as remedy. Economic tensions appear throughout: refused guarantee for house rental, disputes over pricing, attempts to buy/borrow goods (horse, flax, calf skin, pig). His poverty and marginal status likely contributed to conflicts.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony and torture-induced confessions. Jean initially confessed voluntarily after being unable to bear the ceps, then retracted, then confirmed under torture. He eventually withdrew his accusations of accomplices at confrontation, calling himself a liar and perjurer. The case shows classic patterns: economic disputes, reputation built over years, prior accusations, detailed maleficia catalog, and escalating confessions under torture. Jean's poverty and marginal status as shoemaker appear central to conflicts. Notable is his claim that sabbat was 'all illusion' and that witches often think they're there but don't leave the house.
